subject: Languages
title: Lenition: How Sounds Wear Down
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Lenition: How Sounds Wear Down.

hook.text: Languages are lazy. Over time, hard consonants soften, weaken, and sometimes vanish completely.

buildup.text: Lenition is the weakening of consonants â€” a 'p' becomes 'b,' a 'b' becomes 'v,' a 'v' disappears.

discovery.text: Latin 'ripa' (riverbank) became Spanish 'riba' then French 'rive' â€” the p weakened step by step.

twist.text: Celtic languages show extreme lenition â€” Irish has an entire system of 'mutations' from this process.

climax.text: Lenition happens because speakers naturally reduce effort â€” the mouth takes shortcuts over centuries.

punchline.text: Given enough time, every consonant dissolves. Language is built on fading sounds.

quiz.question: What is lenition?
